Award.AwardTitle: An On-Chip, Nanomechanics Platform for Lithium Storage Capacity Measurements in Single Nanowire Electrodes

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this award is to develop an experimental technique for directly quantifying the intrinsic lithium storage capacity of an individual nanowire (NW) electrode with attogram-scale precision. A lithium ion battery electrode represents a nanomechanical system in which both the stiffness and mass are modulated dynamically with charging or discharging. These dynamic nanomechanical signatures of the battery electrode will be probed within the experiments. Electrokinetically assembled, on-chip, single-NW electrochemical cells will be fabricated such that the electroactive NW forms a doubly-clamped beam and remains suspended between metallic current collectors. At any given lithiation state, static force vs. deflection measurements using an atomic force microscope will be employed to determine the nanomechanical stiffness of the suspended NW electrode. Furthermore, NW resonance frequency will be measured using in-situ electron microsopy based characterization of electrostatically actuated nanowires. This combination of static force-deflection and in-situ resonance measurements will enable the extraction of its lithiation / de-lithiation induced mass change at any given charge state.

This effort would result in a new multiphysics diagnostic capability for energy storage systems based on nanostructured materials and would extend the relevance / capabilities of the mechanics community into electrochemical energy storage research in new directions. The award will entail research collaborations with the Sandia National Laboratories (SNL) and a graduate student from Virginia Commonwealth University will have opportunities to perform a part of his research at SNL. An undergraduate Summer Cadet from the Virginia Military Institute will also participate in a summer project at the PI's lab, as a part of the VCU-VMI research exchange program, and will perform in-situ microscopy experiments. The educational outreach activities will bring advanced microscopy and electrochemical energy storage topics into graduate and undergraduate curricula.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project has delivered new experimental techniques and new knowledge, which advance the current understanding of structure-property-performance relationships in lithium-ion (Li-ion) battery electrodes. The entire study has been performed using electrochemical cells where a single electroactive nanowire performs the role of a cathode. The use of nanostructured electrodes at a single-particle level in these experiments was motivated by the following reasons: (1) potential for improved performance with nanostructured electrodes in terms of capacity, rate capability and cycle-life, and (2) the suitability of nanostructured electrodes to study and optimize battery materials at the atomic-to-nanoscale.

This two-year effort has resulted in the following original contributions: (1) a capability to assemble single nanowire electrochemical cells on silicon chips, involving multiple new material systems, (2) an electrochemically-correlated study to understand the impact of electronic conductivity changes in a battery electrode on its charge storage capacity, (3) new insights into the correlation between elastic properties of a battery electrode, which in turn play a role in its mechanical stability and cycle-life, and its state-of-charge, and (4) a proof-of-concept demonstration of a nanomechanical apparoach for charge capacity measurements at a single nanowire-level. Much of these experiments have involved different phases of manganese oxides and the new knowledge gained is essential to advance the performance of these "green" material systems towards eventual insertion in next-generation sustainable energy solutions.

The results from this project have resulted in three published journal articles and one conference publication. In addition, one journal article is under review and one conference abstract has been accepted for presentation. Furthermore, three graduate students (two at the Doctoral and one at the Masters level) have received a substantive part of their degree training through the research activities related to this project. One doctoral and one Masters student have also benefitted from collaborative research visits (lasting a month or longer) to the Center for Integrated Nanotechnologies at Sandia Labs, Albuquerque. These visits have added unique value to their educational program in terms of both, collaborations with scientists at this leading DOE Nanoscience facility and in terms of access to state-of-the-art nanoscience tools, which are not commonly available in academic facilities.

Other societal impacts include educational outreach activities beyond the funded institution (i.e., VCU). This includes a summer undergraduate cadet from the Virginia Military Institute (VMI), who performed nanomechanics experiments within the scope of this project through the VCU-VMI summer research initiative. Minority outreach was accomplished through the educational activities, which were designed for high-school students on nanoscale microscopy, within the scope of the Richmond Area Program for Minorities in Engineering (RAPME). In addition, the contributions from this project have been instrumental in promoting synergistic interactions among the broader research and professional community in the areas of experimental nanotechnology, mechanics and materials science. This has been enabled by the PI's participation in co-editing a special topic for an American Society of Mechanical Engineers (ASME) journal, apart from his active service on the ASME Nanomaterials for Energy technical committee and its associated conferences.


Last Modified: 08/13/2015
Modified by: Arunkumar Subramanian
